identificationModule.briefTitle: Effect of Endotoxin on Alcohol Consumption
identificationModule.officialTitle: Does Endotoxin Administration Increase Alcohol Consumption in Individuals With AUD?

collaborators.name: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: For this protocol, the investigators plan to collect pilot data to examine the effect of endotoxin on drinking behavior in the human laboratory.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
This pilot study is a double-blind, placebo-controlled design, which will compare endotoxin (0.4ng/kg i.v.) to placebo (0.0ng/kg) in non-treatment seeking adults meeting criteria for DSM-5 alcohol use disorders (n=32 total, n=16 per group).

Eligibility screening consists of an intake session and a physical exam. Participants meeting eligibility criteria will be randomized to receive a single dose of 0.4ng/kg i.v. endotoxin or placebo during a single laboratory session to evaluate ad-libitum alcohol consumption.

During the laboratory session, endotoxin (or placebo) administration will precede a 2-hour alcohol self-administration period.

Participants will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment to evaluate drinking behavior.

Adverse events are evaluated during the laboratory session and follow-up, and will be tabulated.

armGroups.label: Endotoxin
armGroups.description: Endotoxin (0.4ng/kg i.v.) will be administered one time during the laboratory session.

armGroups.label: Placebo
armGroups.description: Administered one time during the laboratory session.

primaryOutcomes.description: Mean mls of alcohol consumed for endotoxin and placebo groups during 120 minute alcohol self-administration session.
